docTitle.titlePart:
On-the-Fly Scene Acquisition with a Handy
Multisensor-System

byline.docAuthor:
Benjamin Huhle*, Philipp Jenke* and
Wolfgang Straßer

front.div:
Abstract: We present a scene acquisition system which allows for fast
and simple acquisition of arbitrarily large 3D environments. We propose
a small device which acquires and processes frames consisting of depth
and color information at interactive rates. This allows the operator to
control the acquisition process on the fly. However, no user input or
prior knowledge of the scene are required. In each step of the processing
pipeline color and depth data are used in combination in order to gain
from different strengths of the sensors. A novel registration method is
introduced that combines geometry and color information for enhanced
robustness and precision. We evaluate the performance of the system
and present results from acquisition in different environments.
front.keyword:
Keywords: Scene acquisition, Registration, PMD, NDT, SIFT, Spec-
tral Correspondences

front.note:
Biographical notes: Benjamin Huhle and Philipp Jenke are cur-
rently PhD students at the WSI/GRIS, University of Tuebingen under
supervision of Prof. Straßer and Prof. Schilling. They studied Computer
Science at the same university. Benjamin Huhle's research interests are
in computer vision and 3D scene capturing. In his research, Philipp
Jenke focuses on post-processing of point data acquired by diverse scan-
ning systems.
Wolfgang Straßer studied Electrical Engineering, Communications and
Computer Science at TU-Berlin and received his PhD in 1974. He was
appointed Professor of Computer Science at TU Darmstadt in 1978. In
1986, he founded the graphics research group at University of Tuebin-
gen. The TU Darmstadt awarded Professor Straßer with a honorary
doctor degree for his outstanding contributions to the field of Computer
Graphics in 2000. At present, Straßer is Professor of Computer Science
and adjunct Professor of Mathematics at Tuebingen. He has chaired
many conferences and workshops, and is a fellow of the EG Association.
